This collection contains research materials, notes and correspondence related to the writing of The Rough Road to Justice: The Journey of Women Lawyers in Texas. The book was commissioned by the State Bar of Texas Committee for Women in the Profession in 2003 under the leadership of Ellen Elkins Grimes and funded in part by a grant from the State Bar Association as well as other donors. Materials are arranged by function, with each series referring to a type of document. Materials are arranged by subject within each series.
Notes pertaining to the research and writing of Rough Road to Justice: The Journey of Women Lawyers in Texas.
Research notes organized by chapter.
Original Manuscript for Rough Road to Justice: the Journey of Women Lawyers in Texas.
Contacts and Correspondence related to the research and writing of Rough Road to Justice: The Journey of Women Lawyers in Texas.
Photographs of Texas women lawyers collected during research for Rough Road of Justice; The Journey of Women Lawyers in Texas.
Books used in the research and writing of Rough Road to Justice: the Journey of Women Lawyers in Texas.
This collection includes photos of Rose Club events, yearbooks that catalog membership, secretarial records and correspondence, and several scrapbooks. The majority of the materials are arranged chronologically and in the order they were received from donors.
This series includes digital archival materials, which are indicated by the term [digital]. A digital copy of the CD can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. These materials may require up to one week to access. Contact curator Vince Lee (velee@uh.edu) for more information.
This collection contains materials related to the establishment of the Auxiliary fundraising board of the Houston Center for Hearing and Speech, formerly known as the Houston School for Deaf Children. Press clippings, school newsletters, copies of speeches, and gala and meeting invitations are all included.
This series contains the student and staff yearbooks for the Houston Center for Hearing and Speech, formerly known as the Houston School for Deaf Children.
This series contains publicity clippings, scrapbooks, correspondence, newsletters, and speeches related to the Auxiliary of the Houston Center for Hearing and Speech.
This collection contains research and draft materials from Claudia’s book and journalist work such as notes, editors’ commentary, final publications, promotional materials, and more. Claudia’s journals written during the drafting of her book are also included.
This series contains materials related to Claudia Kolker’s book, The Immigrant Advantage: What We Can Learn from Newcomers to America about Health, Happiness, and Hope, including manuscripts, bibliographic material, interview notes, publicity, etc.
This series contains materials related to Claudia work as a journalist and staff writer, including drafts, research, notes, and final published articles.
This series contains miscellaneous materials such as Claudia’s journals, personal calendars, and other miscellanea.
This collection contains materials related to Marcella Perry's work as a banker and politician between 1945 and 1985. The contents are broken up into two series: News, Events, and Correspondence; and Photos, Scanned Documents, and Scrapbooks. The sequencing is chronological and maintains the original structure created by Marcella and her family as closely as possible.
This series contains news clippings, correspondence, and event invitations related to Marcella Perry's work as a bank executive and port commissioner. Digital archival materials can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room. Contact curator Vince Lee (velee@uh.edu) for more information.
This series contains scrapbooks, photo sheets, and items from the folders Marcella's family labeled "Scanned Documents."
This collection contains items created between 1959 and 2013 related to the Texas Society of Professional Engineers (TSPE) and their Auxiliary, with a concentration on the Houston branch. The materials are broken up into series and organized chronologically within those series, with particular attention given to the original organization of the materials. There are meeting minutes, president’s records, relevant publications, and other miscellanea.
This collection is predominantly comprised of documents related to Betty Jukes’ nearly fifty years as an event planner, philanthropist, and volunteer in Houston. Organizations of note that Mrs. Jukes was involved with include the Houston Junior Woman’s Club, The Woman’s Club of Houston, the Charles A. Lindbergh and Anne Morrow Lindbergh Fund, and more. Spanning the years of 1967 through 2014, this collection also includes various awards and ephemera that Betty Jukes received throughout her career, and many interesting letters of correspondence between Mrs. Jukes and persons of note such as Lady Bird Johnson and Ima Hogg. Items are filed according to organizational affiliation and year.
This series contains materials related to the First Junior Woman’s Club of Houston, the Houston Junior Woman’s Club, and the Woman’s Club of Houston.
This series contains materials from activities related to the Charles A. Lindbergh and Anne Morrow Lindbergh Fund, an organization that funds scientific grants focused on environmental conservation and technological innovation. Also included here are Jukes’ files related to the Mercury Seven scholarship fund and the 1982 World Wildlife Foundation of Houston’s dinner honoring His Royal Highness Prince Philip of England.
This collection has materials related to various benefit galas and luncheons that Jukes planned over the course of her career. Included here are planning materials and invitations from the Houstonians of the Year dinner and Clean Houston Proud Partners’ Luncheon.
This series contains materials from the Houston Youth Symphony and Ballet, the University of Houston Moores’ School of Music Society, the West Point Cadets Glee Club Concerts, the Houston Grand Opera and the Theater Under the Stars of Houston, the Houston Symphony—Women’s Committee, and various Houston museums.
This series contains materials from Betty Jukes’ work related to St. Joseph’s Hospital, St. Luke’s Hospital, the Huffington Center on Aging, the Mental Health Association of Texas, the American Cancer Society, and the Houston March of Dimes.
This series contains miscellaneous photos related to Houston public works and parks. Additionally, materials from the short-lived Aquarium Society of Houston and other miscellaneous philanthropic projects of Betty Jukes’ reside here.
This collection is housed in 45 boxes and organized into 12 series entitled: Buffalo Bayou Partnership, Market Square Park Project, Art Lies (the magazine), good (the book), Blaffer Gallery, Friends of Integrative Medicine, Uncommon Cents, News clippings, photographs, A/V Materials, and Ephemera/Index Cards. Materials within this collection have been arranged topically and therein in chronological order.
This series documents one of the major projects in which Toni Beauchamp was involved in a leadership role. It contains well-documented information that gives an account of the various roles and projects executed by Toni Beauchamp and others in developing the Buffalo Bayou Master Plan for Buffalo Bayou Park (BBP). It is further broken down into various subseries that detail history, correspondence, board of director, professional consultation/development, financials, networking/publicity, memoranda, projects, and other information as it relates to BBP.
This series, represnting another major project in which Toni Beauchamp was involved in a leadership role, contains detailed and documented information that gives an account of the various roles and works that Toni and others executed in relation to the Market Square Park Project (MSPP). The documents highlight the development and progression of the project. This series is further sub-divided into subseries that include history, projects, correspondence, financials, funding, board of directors, professional consultant, and printed materials related to MSPP.
This series details another major project in this collection: Toni Beauchamp’s long-running affiliation with Art Lies magazine (now a part of Gulf Coast Magazine, a project of UH Creative Writing Program). The Series is further broken down into various subseries that deal with history, projects, correspondence, management, government relations, committees, financials, and articles, all in relation to Art Lies.
This series represents the fourth major project detailed in this collection. It consists of various elements of good, the book that Toni edited and produced in recognition of the new century: her Millennium Project. She commissioned artist Mel Chin to produce a sculpture (subsequently gifted to MFA,H) and cover art, and local people from all walks of life to write their story of being in Houston; edited the resulting essays; and produced the book. The Series is further broken down into various subseries that deal with history, projects, correspondence, management, Government relations, committees, financials, and articles relating to good.
This series represents the fifth major project detailed in this collection. It consists of various projects and events with which Toni Beauchamp was affiliated in relation to Blaffer Gallery, University of Houston. This Series is further broken down into subseries that deal with projects, correspondence, management, and articles relating to the Blaffer.
This series documents the sixth major project in this collection. Toni conceived, founded, and led FIM until her death in 2012, after which it continued as a project of UTMDACC. The Series consists of various projects and events with which Toni Beauchamp was affiliated in relation to Friends of Integrative Medicine. This Series is further broken down into subseries that deal with projects, correspondence, management, and articles relating to FIM.
This series represents the seventh major project in this collection. It consists of various projects and events with which Toni Beauchamp was affiliated in relation to Uncommon Cents, an investment “club” that Toni co-conceived, co-founded, and led. This Series is further broken down into subseries that deal with projects, correspondence, management, and articles relating to Common Cents.
This series documents various other projects Toni Beauchamp was affiliated with in Houston’s Art Community/Organizations and her other varied interests. This series is further broken down into subseries that are characterized by the names of these other groups, including Cultural Arts Council of Houston/ Harris County; Museum of Fine Arts, Houston; Contemporary Art Museum Houston, and Orange Show; as well as arts advocacy.
This series consists of full newspapers and newspaper and magazine clippings that contain information regarding the various projects with which Toni Beauchamp was affiliated, as well as general subject matters that were of interest to her. Some of the topics that can be found in this series include Robert Wilson, arts and architecture, John Biggers, Market Square Park, and real estate, among others.
This series consists of photographs of various projects and events in which Toni Beauchamp was engaged. The pictures consist of projects such as; DiverseWorks, Market Square Park, and the Millennium Project, among others. Each project and event is separated into folders as listed below:
This series consists of VCD’S, CD’s and Disk players that contains information relating to the  various projects and events in which Toni Beauchamp was engaged. These projects include; Buffalo Bayou Park, DiverseWorks, Market Square Park, James Johnson Sweeney, Toni’s thesis research, and Friends of Integrative Medicine.
This series consist of Ephemera such as awards given to Toni Beauchamp and Index cards that she used to take notes while carrying out various research for projects.
This collection includes the photographs, publications, and ephemera belonging to the North America Taiwanese Women’s Association. Materials are arranged topically and then chronologically, whenever possible. The series included are: Photo Albums/Scrapbooks, Publications, and Ephemera. The bulk of the materials are written primarily in Taiwanese except for the cookbooks which also include the English translation of the text.
This series contains photo albums and scrapbooks maintained by NATWA. All materials for the corresponding year were contained in individual albums or binders. The binders and albums have been deconstructed and preserved in archival sleeves though the original order has been maintained. Two oversized albums remain intact and can be located in OVS Box 5. Any written material and photograph captions within this series are written primarily in Taiwanese.
This series consists of printed materials published by NATWA. Included are the complete collections of membership directories, convention handbooks, magazines and calendars. The calendars are an important part of the NATWA tradition. First thought of by Ms. Annette Lu as a means to promote Taiwan, the calendars began with a donation by Japanese businessman Ing-Ke Kao and the annual publication has been instrumental in the organization’s financial success. All publications held in this series are primarily written in Taiwanese.
This series contains materials related to NATWA but does not fit into any previous series. Included are banners, scarves and a pin all decorated with the NATWA logo.
This collection consists of the research materials of Drs. Judith McArthur and Harold Smith. Included are copies of materials held at other institutions as well as the authors’ notes. The collection is divided into six series: Minnie Fisher Cunningham, People, Conventions/Conferences, Organizations/Committees, Issues, and Photographic Material. All materials relate to Minnie and her various efforts across differing fields of interest. The bulk of the papers consist of correspondence between Minnie and individuals and organizations. The series is organized thematically and alphabetically.
Note: A significant portion of the materials included in the collection are photocopies or reprints acquired from institutions other than the University of Houston and as such the holding institution must be cited where applicable.
This collection includes materials related to the UH Women’s Resource Center. The collection is broken into four series: General Information, Advertisements, Organizations and Printed Materials.
This series contains materials directly related to the WRC. Included are meeting minutes, articles about the center and various other materials pertaining to the organization.
This series consists of advertisements placed in the Daily Cougar, the University of Houston daily newspaper. The materials consist mainly of advertisements of events held by the WRC.
This series contains materials related to organizations with which the WRC worked closely. Both organizations, like the WRC, focus on support and networking of women on the University of Houston campus.
This series consists of printed materials not directly related to the WRC. Transitions is a magazine for new students.
This collection includes materials related to the University Commission on Women (UCW). The majority of the materials included in the collection revolve around the governance and operation of the organization with a large series being dedicated to the mentoring program. The collection consists of six series: Governance, Meetings, Mentoring Program, Reports, Research, and General Information.
This series consists of material related to the operation of the University Commission of Women. Included are bylaws, a brief history of the UCW, as well as information regarding scholarships and members.
This series contains materials related to the meetings of the UCW. The second sub-series consists of meeting materials as well as other materials distributed during the meetings. The third sub-series contains only meeting minutes.
The materials contained in this series relate to the UCW mentoring program. The UCW established the program after conducting a study on the need for mentoring in 2004. The program was designed to help mentors and mentees develop to their full professional potential and provide economic benefits to the University of Houston.
This series consists of reports conducted by the UCW. Included are reports on child care, domestic partner benefits and executive summaries. Of importance is the Report on the Status of Women from October 2007, the first conducted by the UCW.
This series contains research materials of the UCW. Included are surveys as well as statistics concerning the University of Houston and comparable educational institutions.
This series consists of materials related to the UCW that do not fit into the previous series. Included are articles pertaining to the UCW, organizational brochures, and information related to Jeanneret Associates, a consulting firm employed by the UCW.
This collection includes articles written by Karkabi, correspondence, notes and research materials. The collection is divided into ten series: Personal, Articles, Correspondence, Appointment Books, Houston Chronicle , Notes, Multi-Media, Publications, Research, and Ephemera. All series are arranged topically and chronologically.
This series contains materials directly related to Karkabi. Included are a short biography and a resume submitted for a seminar on youth mental health.
This series consists of articles written by Karkabi over her career. The majority of the articles were written for the Houston Chronicle, but the series also contains articles published in other newspapers and noted as such.
This series contains correspondence sent to Karkabi. Most of the materials consist of letters or emails concerning articles Karkabi wrote.
This series consists of day and monthly planners and message books. The monthly and day planners note appointments and scheduling, while the message books note missed calls. The day planner sub-series is incomplete with missing months for some years.
This series contains material directly related to the Houston Chronicle. Most of the material revolves around daily operations and internal issues of the paper. Also included are profiles and materials related to “Yo! Houston,” a feature on Houston teens.
This series consists of Karkabi’s reporter’s notebooks. The notebooks have been divided by topic where any discernable topic is known. A large number of notebooks have been grouped into OVSBox 10.
This series contains audio, video, and photographic material related to Karkabi or her research. The majority of materials included do not revolve around Karkabi herself but with research for her articles. Included are photographs and an oral history with Mary Ann Kokernot Lacy conducted by Karkabi.
This series consists of publications Karkabi collected for research for articles she wrote. The publications do not include any of Karkabi’s work. The majority of the material contained within the series relates to religious or health issues.
This series contains materials Karkabi used for research purposes. The majority of the materials found in this series relate to religious or health issues. Karkabi did extensive research on Muslims as well as religious organizations and religious centers in the Houston area.
This series consists of materials Karkabi collected in the course of her work. Of particular interest are odd religious centered artifacts such as the “Deseret honey” crafted by the Latter Day Saints as well as an unopened tin of adhesive bandages sporting images of Jesus. Also included are two journalism awards won by Karkabi.
The collection is primarily concerned with the River Oaks Area Democratic Women, though it also contains material for both Democrat and Republican political candidates. Material in the collection includes correspondence, business and financial records, photographs, and the organization’s publication, Register. The collection is divided into six series: Governance, ROADwomen Register, Events and Programs, Organizations, Campaign Materials, and Various Materials. All series are arranged topically and chronologically except for Organizations and Campaign Material, which are organized alphabetically by name group or candidate.
The series is the largest of the collection and is comprised of materials related to the governance of ROADwomen including financial and membership records, by-laws and other material pertaining to the incorporation of the organization. The sub-series concerned with meetings consist of materials and clippings pertinent to the meeting in question but are not meeting minutes.
This series consists of the organization’s newsletter. Each folder contains the newsletter that corresponds to the date and most contain drafts of the newsletter as well as materials included in the publication. Register primarily focuses on the activities of ROADwomen but also discusses issues pertinent to the organization.
This series contains materials on events hosted by ROADwomen as well as programs in which the organization participated. Arianna Live! is an event that featured Arianna Huffington, president and editor-in-chief of the Huffington Post. The Fork in the Road Benefits were held by ROADwomen as fundraisers for the organization and as a means to periodically give money to various Democratic clubs, organizations, and candidates, as well as to further the general mission of the group.
This series consists of flyers, brochures, and general information about the corresponding organization. The folders regarding the Harris County Democratic Party contain more information, such as correspondence between members of ROADwomen and the HCDP, as the two organizations worked closely together.
This series contains campaign materials for both Republican and Democrat candidates. The materials include flyers, stickers and other items pertaining to the candidates’ campaigns. Local Houston area, Texas state and national races are represented within the series. The voters guides are items released by different organizations and not specifically by ROADwomen.
This series consists of materials that do not fit into any other series. The materials included are business cards, a VHS tape, a print out of the Declaration of Independence, as well as various newspaper and magazine clippings regarding varied issues.
This collection includes speeches, written works, as well as DVDs and photo CDs that document civic and professional life of Andrea White, former First Lady of Houston, housed in one box and comprised of three series.
This series is comprised of speeches and presentations White delivered to various civic and volunteer groups between 2007 and 2010. Included are the original stump speeches she gave while her husband, Bill White, was a participant in the 2010 Texas gubernatorial race.
This series documents the development of Andrea White’s popular young adult fiction books. Included are translations of her works, Window Boy, and Surviving Antarctica, in Hungarian, Simplified Chinese, and Greek.
