Laws Administered by EEOC, OVS KF3464.A6U55 1985
HQ1439.H68G74 1994
This collection is housed in 9 boxes and organized into 5 series. The content of the collection consists of Houston Comet’s memorabilia documenting their four WNBA championship wins from years 1997 to 2000. In addition, general Houston Comet’s novelty items can be found in this collection dating from the year 1997 to 2003.
The John H. Lienhard series of speeches and materials cover a diverse range of topics. The earliest speech dates from 1962 and the most recent in the collection dates from November 1997. The vast majority of speeches from the collection were given between 1980 and 1997.
This series is the largest in the collection consisting of over 600 talks given to various groups by Professor Lienhard between 1961 and 2002. The series is arranged chronologically and the talks retain the titles used by Dr. Lienhard.
This series consists of various drafts of two textbooks written by Professor Lienhard; Statistical Thermodynamics and A Heat Transfer Textbook. The folders in this series contain preliminary drafts, page proofs, galley proofs, correspondence, and royalty statements for the works.
~20 linear feet
The papers of Edison Ellsworth Oberholtzer contain employment contracts, information relating to the University of Houston, photographs, newspapers, certificates, and diplomas. Dr. Oberholtzer's papers are arranged in five series. The collection contains material dating from 1905 to 1967. A few of the photographs may precede 1905. Most of the material was obtained from Richard A. Walker in January 2003. Mr. Walker is a Professor of Geography at the University of California, Berkeley and a grand nephew of Dr. Oberholtzer.
This series consists of four folders containing the employment contracts for E.E. Oberholtzer, dating from 1911 to 1950 and arranged chronologically.
This series consists of twenty-one folders, probably office files, relating to various aspects of the University of Houston.
This series consists of seven folders relating to personal aspects of the Oberholtzer family. The materials date from 1910 to 1959 and are arranged alphabetically.
This series contains four folders of miscellaneous materials dating between 1924 and 1967 and arranged chronologically.
This series contains four folders containing family photographs spanning the life of E.E.Oberholtzer.
This series contains fourteen diplomas or certificates awarded to the Oberholtzers that date between 1904 and 1959 and are arranged chronologically.
This series contains five newspapers arranged chronologically.
This collection includes two naval uniforms and a panoramic photograph.
One buckle has come detached from the strap.
Photograph has damage to corner, but image is clear.
This collection contains eighty-eight vintage postcards collected by E. Virginia Barnett. The collection includes materials from Arkansas, California, Illinois, New Jersey, New York, Texas, Virginia, Oregon, Washington and Washington D.C. Some items are booklets containing several views of a particular event or locale. The collection is organized by state, and then further subdivided by city.

The collection contains the transcripts and cassettes of the Phi Kappa Phi oral history interviews. A small amount of written material and three computer diskettes are also included with the collection. All materials date from 1978 to 1985. The cassettes have been boxed separately for preservation reasons.
The Schlayer Collection contains the typescript and galleys for the book How to Be a Financially Secure Woman (New York: Rawson Associates, 1977).  The collection consists of three documents: a photocopy of the typescript, and two sets of galley proofs, one marked “Author’s reading set 1 of 2”, and the other “Author’s reading set 2 of 2.”
This collection contains photographs, correspondence, newspaper clippings, short stories, and articles related to or written by Donald Barthelme and his brothers, Rick, Steve, and Peter Barthelme, as well as notes by Helen Barthelme. This collection contains research that Helen Barthelme gathered in order to write a biography on Donald Barthelme Jr., Donald Barthelme: The Genesis of a Cool Sound. This collection encompasses his early life and career both as a writer and as director of the Contemporary Arts Association, up until his death in 1989.
This series includes copies of typescript program proposals for the Contemporary Arts Association (CAA) and the Contemporary Arts Museum, CAA publications, copies of newspaper articles about CAA, and other miscellaneous materials.
Contains microfiche copies of newspaper articles about CAA during Donald Barthelme's tenure as member of the board and director.
This series includes original, and copies of typescript letters written by Donald Barthelme to his family during his army service in Korea, to Helen Barthelme during and after their marriage, and to friends and family. The series also includes letters to Donald Barthelme from friends, postcards, telegrams, and other miscellaneous items. Some letters included are outside the chronological scope of the early years of Donald Barthelme's life.
This series contains photographs from Donald Barthelme's time in Korea, his selective service cards and honorable discharge certificate from the US Army, and family photographs, slides, negatives, and proofs.
This series includes correspondence between Donald Barthelme and contributors to the Forum during 1956-1960, arranged alphabetically by contributor name. Included are letters from such noted contributors as Robert Bly, Irving Howe, Alfred Kazin, Norman Mailer, and Harold Rosenberg. Some folders also include additional materials related to Forum contributors such as reprints of articles, photocopied bibliographies of works, photocopies of obituaries, and annotated lists of correspondence. Also included is correspondence related to a proposed meeting of editors of similar journals and miscellaneous administrative materials.
This series includes original and copies of Forum magazines and other miscellaneous materials.
This series contains several photocopies and originals of the published versions of early short stories by Donald Barthelme, an original typescript of his essay "Not-Knowing," and miscellaneous materials related to Barthelme's writing work. It also includes a listing of the published versions of short stories, which were cataloged and removed from the collection.
This series contains copies of newspaper and magazine articles about Barthelme and his work, interviews, reviews of works, and miscellaneous critical materials. Also included are programs for book readings of Barthelme's works and receptions honoring Barthelme, as well as the announcement of the Barthelme Memorial Fellowship award.
This series includes copies of newspaper articles on the Barthelme brothers, reviews of their works, and essays published by Steven Barthelme. The series also contains copies of 'The Texas Observer' during Steven Barthelme's tenure as review editor and contributor.
This series includes notes for Helen Barthelme's book, analysis of Donald Barthelme's works, interviews with friends of Donald Barthelme, biographies and bibliographies of contributors to Forum, newspaper and magazine articles about Donald Barthelme, and other miscellaneous materials.
This series includes manuscripts, notes, and diaries by Helen Barthelme, drafts of fictional works, poems, and essays, including Dr. Barthelme's classwork.
These records contain 1 box relating to the Houston Alumni Organization. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Materials include manuals, certificates, event programs and flyers, promotional material, fundraising material, newsletters, published material, reports, correspondence, posters, and stationary. The collection is arranged chronologically and then alphabetically when necessary. Material ranges in date from the 1960’s to 2009.
These records contain 9 boxes, 9 oversize folders and 1 scrapbook, all relating to the various athletic teams of the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the University Print Plant. Material includes correspondence, stationery, publications, program guides, press guides, newspaper clippings, handbooks, and scrapbooks. This collection is organized into 5 series; General Information, Programs, Championship Publications, UH Athletic Publications and Miscellaneous Athletic Publications and Clippings. Each series is arranged alphabetically by athletic team or committee, and then chronologically when necessary. Materials range in date from the 1950’s to 2010.
These records contain 7 boxes relating to the C.T. Bauer College of Business at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Materials include course information, event programs and flyers, posters, invitations, report, correspondence and stationary.  Also included in this collection is a Publications series that includes reports, manuals, surveys, newsletters, and conference material. This collection is arranged chronologically and alphabetically as necessary. Material ranges in date from the 1940’s to 2009.
This collection contains records relating to the Hines College of Architecture at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Records include course information, promotional material, invitations, correspondence, reports, faculty writings, publications, commencement programs, and stationary. The collection is arranged chronologically and alphabetically as necessary. Material ranges in date from the 1940’s to 2009. In addition, the collection includes more than 80 posters, many of which were produced by students, faculty, and staff in-house. An additional box of records transfered from the Architecture and Art Library is not yet fully processed.
These records contain 9 boxes relating to the various departments that make up the College of Liberal Arts and Social Sciences at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Material includes correspondence, course information, event programs and flyers, invitations, promotional material, published material, newsletters, stationary, Self-Study reports, and Five-Year plans. The collection is arranged alphabetically by department title. Material ranges in date from the 1930s to 2009.
These records contain 6 boxes relating to the College of Education at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Materials include course information, workshop flyers, research papers, instructional materials, event flyers, correspondence, certificates, newsletters, teaching programs. Included in this collection is a Publications series that includes faculty studies, and administrative reports. This collection is arranged chronologically and alphabetically as necessary. Materials range in date from the 1940s to 2009.
These records contain 2 boxes and 1 oversize folder relating to the University of Houston Law Center. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Material includes certificates, registration material, correspondence, course information, event programs and flyers, reports, newsletters, stationary, and published material. This collection is arranged alphabetically by department, program, or subject title. Material ranges in date from the 1930s to 2009.
These records contain 4 boxes and 1 oversize folder relating to the College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Material includes correspondence, course information, event programs and flyers, program guides, publications, newsletters and faculty reports. This collection is arranged alphabetically by department title and chronologically as necessary. Within each department, material is arranged by the following categories: General Information, Guides, Newsletters, Publications, and/or Reports. Materials range in date from the 1940s to 2009.
These records contain 2 boxes relating to the College of Optometry at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Materials include newsletters, correspondence, event programs and flyers, administrative material, published material, course information, reports, patient forms, and stationary. Included in this collection is a series of taped interviews. The collection is arranged chronologically and alphabetically as necessary. Material ranges in date from the 1950s to 2009.
These records contain 1 box relating to the College of Pharmacy at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Material includes correspondence, course information, event programs and flyers, stationary, newspaper articles, abstracts, magazines, and other published material. The collection is arranged chronologically. Material ranges in date from the 1950s to 2009.
These records contain 2 boxes relating to the College of Technology at the University of Houston. Material includes booklets, flyers, reports, handbooks, manuals, and video tapes. This collection is arranged chronologically and alphabetically as necessary by the following series; booklets and flyers, and videos. Materials range in date from the 1940s to 2009.
These records contain 3 boxes relating to the Conrad N. Hilton College of Hotel and Restaurant Management at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Material includes correspondence, course information, event flyers, posters, proposals, certificates, stationary, promotional material, invitations, newsletters, published material, newspapers, memorandum, proposals, and two plaques. This collection is arranged chronologically and alphabetically as necessary. Material ranges in date from the 1960s to 2009.
These records contain 10 boxes relating to the Cullen College of Engineering at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Material includes event programs and flyers, co-op program material, newsletters, brochures, correspondence, stationary, course lectures, and published material. Included in this collection are the following series: General Information, Mechanical Engineering NASA Class Lectures, and Publications. This collection is arranged alphabetically by department title, and chronologically as necessary. Class lectures are arranged alphabetically while published material is arranged chronologically. Material ranges in date from the 1940s to 2009.
This collection contain 2 boxes of records relating to the Graduate School of Social Work at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Materials include course information, stationary, certificates, invitations, program and workshop flyers, promotional material, published material, newsletters, reports, and commencement programs. This collection is arranged chronologically and alphabetically as necessary. Material ranges in date from the 1960s to 2009.
These records contain 1 box relating to the Honors College at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Materials include certificates, programs information, reports, event flyers, invitations, stationary, correspondence, newsletters, commencement programs, and promotional material. This collection is arranged chronologically. Material ranges in date from the 1940s to 2009.
This artificial collection was created to bring together materials related to the investiture of Presidents and Chancellors at the University of Houston. Materials include programs, invitations, lists of delegates, press coverage, and administrative information related to the production of the investiture ceremony. Presidents covered include Renu Khator, Philip Guthrie Hoffman, Charles Edwin Bishop, and Arthur K. Smith.
This small collection contains memorabilia collected from the revolution. Included with the items are translations provided by the donor.
The collection consists of Sanskrit and Gita scholar Vishnu K. Divecha's work as a translator, teacher, and student of the Bhagavad Gita and other Sanskrit and Hindi works, as well as a library of such works.

From: Scripture/Mahabharata; Section: Udyoga Parva (1 of 18); Chapters: 33 through 39; By: Vidur Mahatma Explanation: Sanskrit break-down, Hindi, and English by Vishnu Divecha. Typescript.
Published works collected by Vishnu Divecha.
This collection contains materials from Voices Breaking Boundaries’ (VBB) history and administration, planning documents, event materials, press clippings and audio-visual materials.
In addition to paper records, this collection also contains digital archival material. Digital archival materials can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. Because not all of these materials are processed, these materials may require up to two weeks to access. Some files may be restricted and not available for access at all. Contact the curator for more information.
This series contains writing samples, paperwork, and lesson plans from camps and workshops provided to teenagers by Voices Breaking Boundaries.
This series contains planning documents, lesson plans, rosters, student writing and reflections from workshops provided to adults and teachers.
This series contains materials related to the organization and promotion of Voices Breaking Boundaries events, art installations, and performances.
This series contains unlabeled photographs and negatives from VBB workshops and events.
This series contains publications and literary compilations created by VBB workshop and event participants.
This series contains press releases and clippings, publicity planning and general or season specific promotional materials.
This series contains event materials including art pieces from various VBB events and art exhibitions.
This series contains administrative paperwork including non-profit board development, board meeting minutes, strategic development and administrative correspondence and contact information.
This series contains documents related to human resources and employment such as employee manuals, job descriptions, hiring processes and correspondence, and staff and artist employment and payment records.
This series contains documents related to the finances and funding of VBB, including grant applications, financial statements and tax information organized by fiscal year.
This series contains documents confirming VBB expenses, including bills, receipts and bank documents.
This series contains a variety of audiovisual materials related to VBB activities including; cassette tapes, VHS tapes, DV tapes, CDs and DVDs.
Folder names reflect original organization and naming. Materials include primarily digital photographs, fliers, and production files. Some fliers that were eventually produced may be duplicated in the print collection. Files were transffered from both Sehba Sarwar's laptop and an external hard drive on September 24, 2015. Files saved at 2014-015_002_vbb. 16.6GB (approximately 18,273 files).

This collection contains materials related to organizational structure of the Houston Area Fiber Artists (HAFA), such as meeting minutes, financial records, secretarial records, membership lists, and more. There is also extensive photographic documentation of various art pieces created by HAFA members, as well as a number of VHS tapes and DVDs showcasing this material.
This Series contains media in a variety of formats, including slides, VHS tapes, and digital materials. Sub-series 2 contains VHS tapes. Due to the fragility of the media, please contact curator Vince lee (velee@Central.UH.EDU) to inquire about viewing the tapes. Sub-series 3, 4, and 5 include digital archival materials. These arrived in the archives in the form of CDs, DVDs, flash drives, and 3.5" floppy disks. The contents have been transferred off these fragile media, but the media type is retained in the finding aid to reflect the original format and organization of the files. The digital files can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. These materials may require up to one week to access. Contact curator Vince Lee (velee@Central.UH.EDU) for more information.
Due to the fragile nature of the media, please contact curator Vince Lee (velee@Central.UH.EDU) with questions about viewing these materials.
The digital files from these CDs and DVDs can be accessed in the Special Collections Reading Room by advance request. These materials may require up to one week to access. In other cases, the titles may have been supplied based on the group of materials in which the discs arrived. The collection also contained 3 CDs that appeared to be blank, despite being labeled. These were labeled "HAFA Backup, May 10, 2008", "HAFA May 2013", and "HAFA Stuff 6/8/06".

In other cases, titles may have been supplied based on the apparent content (file names) of the drives.

Crooker’s papers include documents relating to zoning ordinances, city planning minutes, activities of subdivisions, news clippings on development issues, City Council speakers, and organizations such as Citizens for Zoning. Arrangement follows as closely as possible Crooker’s own organizational schema, with adaptations sufficient to facilitate the third-party exploration of the collection. Collection includes approximately 6 linear feet of materials. Materials cover the period from roughly the 1950s to mid-1990s.
This series covers issues in Houston proper and includes materials related to zoning, restrictive covenants, and formation of citizens’ groups such as the Houston Homeowners Association founded by Kay B. Crooker. Information covers the 1950s through 1996. Topics covered include racial issues in deed restricted neighborhoods, community affairs, press coverage, and neighborhood goals to enhance property values and protect homeowners’ rights.
Series 2 covers specific neighborhood areas inside and outside Houston and the organizations that evolved to protect and develop those areas.
Series 3 includes information on environmental issues that affect urban development and quality of life.
Series 4 includes city planning and park preservation materials that Kay B. Crooker collected for research purposes and for examples of effective and progressive policies.
Collection includes records relating to the formation and development of the Gulf Coast Council on Foreign Affairs and its successor organizations, the Gulf Coast World Affairs Council, and the Houston World Affairs Council. Documents reveal the administrative processes by which the organizations were governed and the various programs and events sponsored by the organizations. Such events include an array of invited speakers, some of considerable note, and trips to various countries, designed to facilitate international understanding and cross cultural experiences.
Collection arrangement follows the trajectory of the three sequentially evolving organizations. Materials generally follow chronological order within sub-series such as Administration, Business Activities, Correspondence, Financial Records, Membership, Programs, and World Affairs Press Coverage.
Materials in this collection represent Hana Ginzbarg’s working files for Armand Bayou. To make the files accessible to the public, they were organized into three series. Series 1 includes materials related to Ginzbarg’s initial campaign to prevent development in the Armand Bayou area. Papers in Series 2 cover the subsequent efforts to preserve Armand Bayou as a nature education center and protect the area from proposed encroachments. Papers in Series 3 include maps and oversized documents.
It should be noted that this collection represents only a portion of Hana Ginzbarg’s papers. She retains her papers related to other campaigns and issues, particularly regarding her exhaustive work on the Bellaire Nature Discovery Center. More of Ginzbarg’s papers will come to the Houston History Archives at a later date.
Series 1 incorporates documents related to the history behind the preservation campaign, including Yramategui’s death, the plans to develop residential housing in the Armand Bayou floodplain, plus the technical and economic reports on Armand Bayou.  Campaign activities are represented in full detail.
Series 2 contains the records of the early days of the Nature Center as an established non-profit entity, including board meetings, financial records, educational programs, and publicity.
This collection includes the records from the Scottish Brigade Alumnae association and the Scottish Brigade. The series included are: Scottish Brigade Alumnae Records; Scottish Brigade Alumnae Photographic and Video Material; Official Brigade Records; Scottish Brigade Performance Material; Scottish Brigade Photographic Material; Scottish Brigade Publicity Clippings; Stephen F. Austin Senior High School Yearbooks; and Scottish Brigade Memorabilia and Scrapbooks.
The Alumnae records include the organizational documents, financial reports, plans for the luncheon and scholarship reports as well as photographs and photo albums of the Alumnae Association activities and luncheons.
The Scottish Brigade records include organizational documents, performance records and plans and photographs of Scottish Brigade members, performances and events. In addition it contains an extensive series of Scottish Brigade memorabilia.
Materials are arranged as Alumnae Records or Brigade records and then arranged by topic within each series. Whenever possible, dated materials are arranged chronologically. The collection is housed in 12 boxes and also includes two oversize items.
This series is comprised of 28 folders housed in 1 box and includes organizational documents, financial records, committee reports and other documents related to the founding and activities of the Scottish Brigade Alumnae Association. Of particular interest is the anthology book A Scottish Brigade Anthology which offers a concise and comprehensive history of the Scottish Brigade, its goals, members and founders.
This series is comprised of 13 folders and 12 items housed in 3 boxes and includes the audiovisual and photographic records of the Scottish Brigade Alumnae association. Most of the items included relate to the Scottish Brigade luncheons although of particular interest are the three Scottish Brigade Performances videos which were created to be shown at the anniversary luncheons.
This series is comprised of 9 folders housed in 1 box and includes the organizational documents of the Scottish Brigade, its financial documents, membership rosters and other administrative documents.
This series is comprised of 37 folders and 4 items housed in 2 boxes and includes documents related to all aspects of the Scottish brigade’s performances. Marching plans, musical scores, song lyrics and marching handbooks are some of the more interesting documents in this series.
This series is comprised of 7 folders and 3 items housed in 3 boxes. This series includes photo albums created by Scottish Brigade members, chronologically organized photos of Brigade members and Brigade events as well as a panoramic photo album containing photos of the entire Scottish Brigade for various years. Please note that Box 11 is an oversize box that contains items from several series and the panoramic photo album is an oversize item housed with the collection, but not in a box.
This series is comprised of 9 folders housed in 3 boxes. This series includes newspaper clippings related to the performances and activities of the Scottish Brigade and its members as well as a run of the Austin Roundup, Stephen F. Austin High school newspaper from 1940-1978. Please note that Box 11 and Box 12 are oversize boxes, and Box 11 contains items from other series.
This series is comprised of 5 folders housed in 1 box. This series includes newspaper clippings related to the performances and activities of the Scottish Brigade and its members as well as a run of the Austin Roundup, Stephen F. Austin High school newspaper from 1940-1978.
This series is comprised of 7 folders and 25 items housed in 6 boxes with one loose item. This series includes costume items, props, marching flags, patches, scrapbooks and other memorabilia from the years that the Scottish Brigade was performing. Please note that Box 12 is an oversize box that contain items from other series and Item 2 is an oversize item housed with the collection, but not in a box.
The processed records in this collection contain 14 boxes relating to the various student organizations at the University of Houston. A significant portion of this material was given to the archives from the university Print Plant. Materials include correspondence, brochures, pamphlets, flyers, club rosters, publications, event programs, and club policies. The bulk of the material consists of records relating to fraternities and sororities on campus; this includes photographs, slides, negatives, and scrapbooks. This collection is arranged alphabetically by organization name, with the fraternity/ sorority records located largely in a separate series. Tau Beta Sigma materials make up a large portion of the collection, and are arranged in their own series. Processed materials range in date from the 1930s to 2009.
Additional materials from the Council of Ethnic Organizations, the Center for Student Involvement, and the Center for Fraternity and Sorority Life were received in 2011 and 2014, and are not yet fully processed. Represented in three "unprocessed" series, these materials date from 1951 to 2014 and constitute an additional 40 linear feet of material.
This series consists of 11 unprocessed boxes containing records transferred from the Council of Ethnic Orgnizations.
This series consists of 28 unprocessed boxes containing records relating to the Center for Student Involvement (CSI) and the fee-funded student organizations it oversees. There is also one OVS folder.
Photograph
This series consists of 1 unprocessed box containing documents, slides and audio tapes relating to the Center for Fraternity and Sorority Life (CFSL) and the fraternities and sororities it supports.
This collection contains theatre programs from 1939-1961.
Houston Heights is situated northwest of downtown Houston, Texas. This Collection contains records from the Houston Abstract Company, the Houston Title Guaranty Company, the Stewart Title Company, and the Southern Abstract and Title Company. This collection consists of 10 abstracts of title and deed for the property in the Heights district, in the city of Houston and Harris County, filed from 1896 to 1941.
This collection is primarily concerned with correspondence from Kenneth Wade Kennedy relating to his World War II service. The collection also includes correspondence from various family members, newspaper clippings relevant to the family, and a small number of musicale programs and wedding invitations.
All letters are arranged chronologically with the exception of a discreet number of letters from various family members which have been arranged alphabetically by author.  Newspaper clippings are undated, while programs and wedding invitations have been arranged chronologically.
Letters from Kenneth W. Kennedy are arranged chronologically and include insights into his time spent at West Point and his role in the Northern Africa campaign of World War II.
Letters from various members of Kenneth W. Kennedy’s family allow for a look into his relations back in the U.S. during World War II. Of particular note are letters from his brother, Joseph Kennedy, sent while working on the discovery of plutonium at the University of California, Berkley and while working on the first atomic bomb at Los Alamos. The fourteenth folder, with letters from various family members, has been arranged chronologically.
Newspaper clippings are undated and relate primarily to various topics of import to the family, but also include references to Kenneth W. Kennedy and his service during World War II.
A small handful of musicale programs and family wedding invitations are arranged chronologically.
The H. David Kaplan Schlumberger Well Services Collection contains information ranging from 1970-1976. Consisting of a single box, this collection includes: employee handbooks and insurance information, awards and certificates, presentations and training materials, an assortment of publications about Schlumberger, and personal and employee correspondence. The publications have been cataloged, and can be located in the UH Library catalog by searching: Schlumberger Sonde Off, Houston Schlumberger Recorder, and Schlumberger Manager.
This collection consists of six volumes of subdivision plat maps of developed areas of Houston, Texas recorded between approximately 1900 and 1970. Five volumes are bound and one is unbound. The pages of the bound volumes are numbered consecutively within each volume. The sixth or unbound volume and is composed of loose sheets, and the pages are numbered but are not in order. The plat maps are not indexed. In addition, the collection contains a separate group of six subdivision plat maps that date from 1961 to 1981, and maps and engineering drawings for the Memorial Chase, Section 3 subdivision dated 1971 to 1973.

This is an artificial and disparate collection of Texana, or materials relating to the history of Texas. In order for the collection to be useful to researchers, an artificial order was imposed by the processor. The collection is divided into seven series: Pre-Republic (to 1836); Republic (1836-1845); Annexation and Early Statehood (1845-1860); Civil War and Expansion (1861-1901); Modern Statehood (1901-1956); Claude Elliott Papers; and Governors Ferguson/Sterling Papers. Series, sub-series, and folder titles have been standardized as much as possible. The first five series, directly relating to Texas history, each contain the same three sub-series: Documents, Printed Material, and Creative Works. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order and items within the folders are arranged chronologically.
The standardized folder titles are fairly broad in order to accommodate the varied nature of the collection. In general, a folder entitled Land will contain deeds; a folder entitled Legal will contain miscellaneous items such as wills and probate documents, indentures, and promissory notes; and a folder entitled Government will contain sheriff’s documents and gubernatorial appointments to local offices. In a few instances, such as with the Annexation of Texas, the amount and focus of the material warrants a specific folder title.
In some instances, items from the twentieth century, such as newspaper or periodical articles, have been placed in an earlier series if the information pertains to an event or person in an earlier period. For example, twentieth century articles on brands have been placed with the nineteenth century brand book.
Some material in the collection was owned previously by Dr. Alexander Dienst, Jr. (1870-1938) of Temple, Texas, a historian and collector of Texana. His handwritten notes and commentary appear on some of the items. He was a friend and supporter of Governor James E. Ferguson.
This series contains Texas materials from the time of Spanish and Mexican rule. The majority of the series comprises manuscripts relating to land, including some written in Spanish.
Typescript of (and correspondence regarding) a presentation made to the Texas State Historical Association, April 25, 1952.
Items in this series pertain to Texas as an independent republic. Items of interest include a promissory note to Mirabeau B. Lamar, president of the Republic; an early Land Book of Texas; a Gonzales County Probate book; a journal by early Texan Ammon Underwood; Colonel Pedro Delgado’s account of the battle of San Jacinto; and accounts of early Texans Peter Gallagher and Robert Potter.
This series contains material relating to the early years of Texas statehood. Items of interest include gubernatorial appointments to local offices, and a Bell County Official Bonds book. Folder 33 contains a document of Public Sale of Land and Negroes dated 1858.
This series contains material pertaining to Texas in the last half of the nineteenth century. Items of interest include three Bell County Stock books and a Bell County Marks and Brands book in two sections; Caldwell County teachers’ paychecks; a book of Bell County taxpayers; a Texas Veterans Association scrapbook; and three copies of the diary of John Lafayette Lane, a Confederate soldier and prospector. One particularly noteworthy item is “A Declaration of the Causes which impel the State of Texas to Secede from the Federal Union” from 1861 (in Sub-Series 2, Box 2, Folder 7).
Of particular note in this sub-series is an item in Folder 7: an eight-page pamphlet from 1861 titled “A Declaration of the Causes which impel the State of Texas to Secede from the Federal Union.”
Includes “A Declaration of the Causes which impel the State of Texas to Secede from the Federal Union,” 1861.
Material in this series concerns the modern state of Texas, beginning in 1901 with the discovery of oil at Spindletop. Items of note include issues of the Congressional Record that pertain to Texas; speeches given by Texas legislators; and an incomplete run of the War Information Series. An item of note is a signed letter from then-Senator Lyndon B. Johnson to Judge C.V. Terrell, dated in 1956 (in Sub-Series 1, Box 2, Folder 22).
This series contains some of Claude Elliott’s scholarship, including entries he wrote for the Handbook of Texas, offprints from journals, and miscellaneous research material.
Items in this series pertain to three early twentieth century Texas governors, James E. and Miriam A. Ferguson, and Ross Sterling. Some of the political items, such as newspaper articles, reference both the Fergusons and Sterling. Of special interest is a holograph diary of James E. Ferguson and letters written by him.
The Business Manager Records of C. F. McElhinney are the records McElhinney generated during his tenure at the University of Houston (1945-1973). The collection has been arranged into six series: Board of Regents, Staff Conference Meetings, Legislative Activities, Building Files, President’s Office, and the Houston College for Negroes. The materials in the collection date from 1945-1974, with the bulk of the materials dating from the 1960s and 1970s. Included in the collection are university-related correspondence, minutes, agendas, reports, financial reports, bids, and contracts. There are no photographs or personal papers in the collection.
Key correspondents in the collection include C. F. McElhinney, Philip Hoffman, Patrick J. Nicholson, E. E. Oberholtzer, W. W. Kemmerer, and Clanton W. Williams.
The materials follow the organization in which McElhinney left them, with some minor rearrangement within folders to follow chronological order. All folder titles use the headings provided by McElhinney.
Materials in the collection document the administrative activities of the University, including Camp Wheeler, construction on the Houston College for Negroes campus (now Texas Southern University), the legislative activities of the University during its campaign for state support in the 1960s, the development of KUHT Channel 8 and KUHF, the campus radio station.
Oversized materials, including maps of campus from the 1960s, blueprints and related architectural materials on the UH Central Power Plant, and a campus map of the utility distribution system have been removed from the collection for preservation purposes. Please ask an Archives staff member for assistance regarding oversize materials.
This is the largest series, 10.5 boxes or 488 folders, with the bulk of the records dating from the 1950s through 1973. The materials are arranged in chronological order with some exceptions and include agendas, minutes, memoranda, reports, budgets and financial reports. Also included in this series are the records of several sub-committees of the Board of Regents/Board of Governors. These include the committees on which McElhinney served: the Finance Committee, the Executive Committee, the Building Committee, the Planning Committee, and the Investment Committee. During 1957 some re-organization was undertaken, which created a Board of Governors to serve in an advisory capacity to the Board of Regents. This changed again in 1963, when the University of Houston gained state funding and the Board of Governors was eliminated. Generally the files are organized by month, with agendas and any attached materials followed by the minutes for that meeting. Of particular interest are materials attached to the minutes and agendas, which include reports or memos from many of the faculty and administrators on campus. These reports address the initiation of new programs on campus as well as several major issues: construction on campus, desegregation, the campaign for state support in the early 1960s, Camp Wheeler, KUHT, and KUHF. These materials have been left with the agendas with which they were attached and therefore are found throughout the series. Materials on KUHT and KUHF, in particular, are scattered throughout this series, although there is a folder from the Ad-Hoc Television Committee in 1959 and a folder specifically on KUHT from 1966.
This series, consisting of 180 folders of material, documents the meetings held by the President of the University with his key administrators. Included in this series are agendas, minutes, correspondence, memoranda, and reports. Major issues, such as construction, finances, KUHT, KUHF, the campaign for state support, student unrest in the 1960s and 1970s, and desegregation are addressed throughout this series. Folders are arranged chronologically.
This series contains [eighty-three folders] arranged chronologically and retaining the folder titles used by McElhinney. Included are reports, minutes, correspondence, memoranda, newspaper clippings, speeches, position papers, state publications, and related materials. This series documents the efforts of the University to achieve state support and status as a state university during the early 1960s and includes the reports sent to the University administration by Patrick J. Nicholson during the 1961 legislative session. Also included are the initial budget requests to the state by the University. One of the primary correspondents in this series is State Senator Robert W. Baker of Houston.
This series, consisting of ninety folders of material, deals with the planning, funding, and construction of the A. D. Bruce Religion Center and the University Center. It is divided into two sub-series, Religious Center and University Center. The bulk of the material dates from 1965 to 1966 and includes subject files, bids, financial records, correspondence, and promotional literature from various companies.
This sub-series, which consists of thirty-four folders, is divided into three sub-sub-series: Subject Files, Architect, and Organ.
The Subject Files are arranged alphabetically by folder title and include planning and fund-raising information.
The Architect sub-sub-series relates to architect Frank C. Dill’s work and the Tellepsen Construction Company. Folders are arranged alphabetically.
The Organ sub-sub-series relates to the various companies that wanted to receive the contract for the Religious Center organ.
This sub-series, which consists of fifty-five folders, is divided into two sub-sub-series, Bids/Worksheets and Subject Files.
This sub-sub-series includes the bids for various aspects of the University Center and worksheets relating to the various bids.
This sub-sub-series is arranged chronologically and includes the minutes and reports of various committees, which addressed the need for a student center on campus in the late 1950s and early 1960s.
This series consists of eighty-nine folders of material and includes correspondence, memoranda, reports, brochures, and other materials generated by or related to the Office of the President. Subjects covered in this series include art on campus, the Clear Lake campus, President Hoffman’s inauguration, and the president’s house. Also included are files with material from General A. D. Bruce, Philip G. Hoffman, and Clanton W. Williams. The materials are divided into the following sub-series: Art, General A.D. Bruce, Clear Lake Campus, Philip G. Hoffman, Inauguration, Clanton W. Williams, and Subject Files. Each sub-series is arranged chronologically.
This series consists of thirty folders of material, dating from 1945 to 1948 and includes receipts, financial records, correspondence, and memoranda. The bulk of the material dates from 1945 to 1947. Included are records from fund-raising efforts for construction of buildings on the campus, as well as financial records for the Houston College for Negroes.
The processed portion of these papers includes 12 linear feet described in five series. They comprise the editorial files for 100 Years of Science and Technology in Texas, published by Rice University Press in 1986. Professor Swenson, of the University of Houston, and Reverend Leo Klosterman, of the University of St. Thomas, co-edited the work, which was sponsored by Sigma Xi, a scientific research society. The materials date from 1977 to 1987.
Included are correspondence with publishers, editors, and authors of the chapters in the books. There are also various drafts of the chapters, page proofs, critiques of the chapters by Swenson, Klosterman, and other contributors, galley proofs, notes, chronologies, outlines, and dust jackets. All chapters and proofs have been arranged according to the arrangement of the published work.
There is also a considerable amount of correspondence and materials related to the Southeast Texas Sigma Xi Council, which sponsored the production of the volume. The minutes of the society, which have been left with the correspondence to which they were attached, provide insight into the organizational and financial difficulties encountered in producing the commemorative volume. Additional materials include items related to the Texas Sesquicentennial and the Robert A. Welch Foundation. Among the Welch Foundation materials were annual reports and research bulletins, published between 1977 and 1984, which have been removed from the collection; copies are available in the University of Houston Pharmacy Library.
The collection has been arranged in six series: Correspondence, Drafts, Proofs, Miscellaneous, Sesquicentennial Materials, and Unprocessed Materials (2015 additions).
This series includes correspondence with contributors as well as correspondence with Sigma Xi members during the period covered by the collection. There is also minimal correspondence with the editors and publishers. There are eighteen folders in this series, with the bulk dating from 1985 to 1986. All correspondence has been arranged chronologically, and attached materials have been kept with their correspondence. Materials sent to Sigma Xi members have a considerable amount of information relating to the status of 100 Years of Science and Technology in Texas.
This series includes multiple drafts of the various chapters in the book, with the editors’ marks. These chapters have been arranged so that different versions of the same chapter are found together, with the overall arrangement following that of the finished book. This is the largest series in the collection, consisting of 110 folders of materials dating primarily from 1986. The materials have been arranged from earliest draft to latest, where differences could be ascertained. Following the chapter drafts are drafts of indexes, chronologies, and general notes made by the editors. This also includes chronologies, indexes, and other book related material. One draft of the book has a rich set of surveys on the history of Sigma Xi chapters in Texas. These materials precede the drafts of the section.
This series includes proofs of the individual chapters in the books, with editing marks. The chapter proofs have been arranged to follow the organization of the finished book. There are also two complete sets of galley proofs of the book, as well as an incomplete set of page proofs. There are thirty-five folders of material in the series, all dating from 1986.
This series includes any material related to the book that does not fall into the three previous series. There are nineteen folders of material dating from 1985 to 1986. Among the items are photographs, publicity material, publishers’ information, notes, lists of possible buyers, and dust jackets. There are also some Sigma Xi materials.
This series includes local press publications from 1986 documenting the history of Texas. There are also several issues of the National Dispatch, which was the official Texas Sesquicentennial publication. The twelve folders in the series have been arranged alphabetically by title.
14 linear feet of additional materials were added to this collection in 2015. Accession #2015-029: 6 boxes of materials donated by Professor Svenson on April 30, 2015. Accession #2015-030: 2 additional boxes of unprocessed archival materials were donated on June 11, 2015. Accession #2015-031: 6 additional boxes of unprocessed archival materials were donated on December 14, 2015.
The Le Bayou collection consists of 20 boxes and is organized into 11 series: Administration, Le Quartier Latin, Correspondence, Submissions, Subscriptions, Le Petit Théâtre Français, Livre d’Or, and Journals, Artistic Stamps, Ledgers, and Photographic Materials. This collection contains papers related to the publication of Le Bayou and includes subscription information, correspondence, and the submissions of both published and unpublished authors. It also includes the papers of Le Quartier Latin, the French Club of the University of Houston, and its publication Le Feuille de Chou. Materials in the Collection date from 1934-1964, and much of it is in the French language.
For preservation and access reasons the collection has been re-boxed and re-foldered. New folder titles conform, as closely as possible, to original folder titles, except when the original was obviously incomplete, incorrect, or confusing. Original folder and item order has been maintained whenever possible. Exceptions were made when folders were obviously misfiled or when no order was apparent.
Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries has in its collection the original Le Bayou, under the call number AP21. B25. The bound volumes begin in 1936, with volume 1, and end with volume 95, in 1963.
This series consists of one box of Le Bayou’s administrative files, and includes documents that reflect the business aspect of an active international literary journal.
This subseries consists of 32 folders of general business concerns, such as advertising, financial documents, correspondence models, copyright, printing, and publicity. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 25 folders, mainly correspondence, that pertains to the organization Friends of Le Bayou. This organization was created to ensure that funds could be donated by interested persons and organizations for the continued financial support of this literary magazine. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 7 folders of materials that relate to Le Bayou’s Campagne de Fonds, a yearly fundraising gathering that took place from 1945 to 1953. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This series consists of 44 folders of materials that relate to Le Quartier Latin, the French club of the University of Houston. It includes general club administrative information, correspondence (organized by date), La Feuille de Chou, its literary newsletter, fundraising events, and relating to exchanges with other magazines. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 18 folders of materials that document the general organization of Le Quartier Latin, such as officer positions and the accompanying duties, membership lists, and financial information. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 8 correspondence folders organized by date. It contains correspondence from individuals, other journals, and organizations. This subseries is organized by date.
This subseries consists of copies of La Feuille de Chou, the newsletter of Le Quartier Latin. It consists of 8 folders organized by date.
This subseries consists of 7 folders of material that relates to several events that were held as fundraisers for the club, in its early years. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of one folder that contains documents relating to the exchange of La Feuille de Chou with other journals and magazines.
This series consists of about two boxes of correspondence, both personal and business. Correspondents of note include E.E. Oberholtzer, the founding president of the University of Houston. This series is organized alphabetically.
This series consists of roughly 3 boxes of material that was submitted for publication in Le Bayou, from its inception to when it stopped publication in 1963. These folders include fiction, poetry, essays, and book reviews, and many of their authors submitted material for many years. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of material submitted for publication in Le Bayou, from its inception to when it stopped publication in 1963. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 46 folders that contain rough draft materials for issues numbering 69 through 71, and for issues numbering 93 and 94. It is organized by issue number, by date, and then alphabetically.
This series consists of three boxes of documents relating to subscriptions, as well as an index card file. It includes general subscriptions, gift subscriptions, individual subscriptions, organizations, and universities. It also includes the materials that contain information concerning the exchange of Le Bayou with other publications, and the orders made by subscription companies. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date. The index card file is at the end.
This subseries consists of 6 folders that relate to subscriptions for Le Bayou from 1938 to 1962.  There is also material relating to orders for Ballades de Mon Bayou.  It is arranged alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of one folder that contains gift subscription orders for Le Bayou from 1950 to 1955.
This subseries consists of 172 folders that contain subscription information for individual subscribers, for Le Bayou from 1941 to 1963. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of roughly 1 and a half boxes of materials relating to subscriptions for Le Bayou by bookstores, libraries, universities, and other kinds of organizations.  It is arranged alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 170 folders of materials that relate to the exchange of Le Bayou with other publications, such as the Berkeley Review and France-Amerique. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 9 folders that contain materials that relates to subscription companies. Some individuals, universities, and organizations ordered their subscriptions through services that provided a large selection, rather than directly ordering from Le Bayou. It is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This sub-series contains subscription information in the form of an index card file. It includes both the subscription information of individual people and organizations. This series is organized alphabetically.
This series consists of 10 folders that contain materials that relate to Le Petit Théâtre Français, including office documents, and copies of its publication La Gazette. Le Petit Théâtre Français was a French theater organization started by Jules Vern. This subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This series consists of 12 folders that contain original and duplicate copies of a scrapbook of clippings relating to Le Bayou and its publicity, from 1950 to 1959. For each original copy, which is organized by date, there is a duplicate copy. This series is organized by date.
This series consists of 2 subseries that consist of Éditions du Bayou and Journals Received. Each subseries is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 16 folders that consist of Éditions de Bayou, a publication series that published small books of poetry, and smaller notebook versions of Le Bayou. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This subseries consists of 11 folders containing journals that Le Bayou either received in exchange from other publications, or were sent in hopes of such an exchange. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This series contains two small boxes of handcarved rubber stamps used in the production of Le Bayou.
This series contains two ledgers of financial information and one receipt book. This series is organized alphabetically, and then by date.
This series contains photographs of members of the Le Bayou staff and includes formal portraits of its founder, Jules Verne. It also contains two photo albums and one scrapbook with photographs of the Le Bayou staff at work and at play. This series is organized by date.
The documents in this collection have been identified as forgeries and were exhibited at a Forgery Conference held at the University of Houston Libraries in 1989.
This collection contains manuscript scores for 6 of Carlisle Floyd's works, dating from 1958 to 1992.
This collection includes slides of life in Eastern Europe and Soviet Russia during the late 1920's to the early 1930's. There are also examples of artwork, monuments, and the palaces of the wealthy.
The UH Core Advisory Committee Records document the development of the University of Houston's Core Curriculum from 1966 to 1992. Materials include university self studies, task force and committee reports, core curriculum documents, and undergraduate council minutes.
This collection consists of two color aerial photographs of Houston, Texas taken in 1972 by the International Aerial Mapping Company of San Antonio.
The photographs show the area around the North Loop Freeway (IH-610) and North Main Street. They measure approximately 9 inches by 9 inches and bear the date "2-4-72" in the upper left hand corner and the serial number "HOU 0724 020" in the upper right hand corner. The back contains the name and address, "International Aerial Mapping, 8927 International Drive, San Antonio, Texas 78216."
This collection consists of one bound volume of color aerial photographs of Houston, Texas taken in 1983 by MPSI Mapping, Inc. of Dallas. It measures approximately 20 inches by 25 inches.
The over-sized bound volume is labeled on the front as "Houston Texas , Southwest," with the name "MPSI" inscribed at lower right. All photographs bear the note, "Date of Photo 12/30/83." The volume is in good condition but has slight water damage to back cover and sheets near the end of the volume.
The Sue Dauphin Houston Area Performing Arts Collection consists of eleven boxes of materials dating from 1947 to 1987. The collection is made up of three series: Houston Area Performing Arts Venues/Groups, Other Performing Arts Venues/Groups, and Sue Dauphin's Papers. Programs from Houston area theatre companies comprise the bulk of the material. Of particular interest is the breadth of coverage from the smallest groups to major arts organizations. A smaller amount of material represents art exhibitions, her correspondence, and newspaper/radio reviews.
PN2277.H68xD37
The collection consists mainly of media records such as articles, magazines, news clippings and newsletters. The collection also contains bills, bill analyses and proposals, speeches and brochures. Other printed materials in the collection include invitations to events, directories, certificates, cards and campaign originals. The ephemeral material consists of pins, posters, special license plates and framed photographs.
The collection has been arranged into ten series: Media, Events, Legislature, Speeches, Electric Utility Restructuring, Campaign, Resources, Photographs, Miscellaneous and Ephemera. The above series have been arranged chronologically, while a couple is sorted topically. The materials in the collection date between 1977 and 2003 and follow original order closely.
The collection is organized in eleven series and housed in 6 boxes. Perhaps the most interesting aspect of the material is the correspondence between the inmates and the organization. The series are organizational material, administrative documents, Goree unit TDC, correction system: laws & conditions, volunteer program, client services, Christmas projects, external correspondence, published information and photographic materials. Of special interest are inmate correspondence, program records and organizational information. These records document to some degree the deplorable conditions of Texas prison system during this era.
This section houses information regarding the organization from its inception in 1971. Organizational documents regarding “Women for Justice” are compiled together.
General Correspondence and organizational meetings and membership rosters and IRS information of the organization etc are available.
Goree Prison Unit visitation program is a very important part of the group and the apparel requests, stationary donations etc happened at regular intervals of time.
The facts about the Texas Department of Corrections, jail reforms and various other information regarding the improvement of the prison system have been compiled together.
Training and recruitment of volunteers, volunteer meetings and various other workshops pertaining to the volunteers has been put together in this series.
This series has a large collection of inmate letters and logs of the prison visitation by volunteers and logs about the donation of apparel to the inmates.
Christmas Project was one of the most important events during any calendar year. The inmates were given gifts and group events were held to get the joyous mood among the prisoners.
This series holds the documents about the organizations and corporate donors who helped “Women for Justice” run the various programs of theirs by monetarily contributions or in any other form.
Printed information about organizations or criminal justice information in general.
Prints and slides of Women for Justice activities/volunteers.
Ninfa’s Papers include business plans, business, personal, and political correspondence, photographs, magazine and newspaper clippings press coverage, proof of public service deeds, scrapbooks, artifacts (buttons and stamps, memorabilia, menus, plaques), and framed enlarged picture and media items and roughly cover the years from 1971 to 2001.
Scenic Houston is a chapter of Scenic Texas, Inc., a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that focuses on promoting policies and actions that enhance the beauty and appeal of our streetscapes and roadways. Scenic Houston works to reduce existing billboard blight, prevent new billboard construction, foster attractive on-premises signage, incorporate context-sensitive design in the planning of highways and other public projects, and protect the natural beauty and distinctive character of our communities for the benefit of successive generations.
Scenic Houston – Scenic Texas Collection includes 9 boxes and records from Billboards Limited, Scenic Houston, Scenic Texas, Scenic America, Scenic Austin, Scenic Dallas, Scenic Fort Worth, Scenic San Antonio, Greater Houston Partnership, Quality of Life Coalition, Scenic Conservation Advisory Council, Houston-Galveston Area Council, Facts and History, Minutes/ Directors and Committees, Events, Street Improvement Projects, Sign Projects, Billboards, Surveys Polls and Public Opinion, Ordinances Legislation, Policy, Statutes, Social Events, and Press Coverage.
Collection of 43 geochemical data maps from locations in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Florida, Kentucky, and Israel between 1944 and 1975, with most maps from the 1940s to 1960s. Within the collection are maps for methane, ethane and heavier hydrocarbons, pentane, soil gas, sand percent, ethane and propane and butane, and total hydrocarbons.
Samples collected July 10, 1974 to July 16, 1974 and December 30, 1974 to January 6, 1975. Total of 387 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes four maps: (1) Methane Map, (2) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map, (3) Pentane Map, and (4) Sand Percent Map.**
Unknown sample collection date. Total of 373 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Methane Map, and (2) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map.**
Samples collected September, 1968. Total of 250 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes one map: (1) Soil Gas Map.**
Samples collected February, 1948 to April, 1948 and December, 1948 to January, 1949. Total of 758 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Ethane Map, and (2) Methane Map.**
Samples collected March 19, 1946 to June 5, 1946. Total of 429 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Total Hydrocarbons Map, and (2) Sand Percent Map.**
Samples collected August, 1968 to September, 1968. Total of 208 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes six maps: (1) Methane Map, (2) Soil Gas (surface) Map, (3) Soil Gas (3') Map, (4) Soil Gas (6') Map, (5) Soil Gas (9') Map, and (6) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map.**
Samples collected October, 1962 to April, 1963. Total of 285 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Methane Map, and (2) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map.**
Samples collected January, 1950 to February, 1950. Total of 405 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Methane Map, and (2) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map.**
Unknown sample collection date. Total of 356 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes three maps: (1) Methane Map, (2) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map, and (3) Total Hydrocarbons Map.**
Samples collected August, 1951 to September, 1951. Total of 72 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map, and (2) Methane Map.**
Unknown sample collection date. Total of 46 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes three maps: (1) Pentane Map, (2) Methane Map, and (3) Ethane and Propane and Butane Map.**
Samples collected April, 1944 to April, 1945, May, 1954 to June, 1954 and May, 1971 to June, 1971. Total of 711 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes four maps: (1) Methane Map (sampled 1944, 1945, and 1954), (2) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map (sampled 1944, 1945, and 1954), (3) Methane Map (sampling supplemented in 1971), and (4) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map (sampling supplemented in 1971).**
Samples collected September, 1964 to November, 1964 and May, 1965 to March, 1966. Total of 1475 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Methane Map, and (2) Iso-Pentane Map.**
Samples collected March, 1945. Total of 356 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes three maps: (1) Ethane and Heavier Hydrocarbons Map, (2) Methane Map, and (3) Total Hydrocarbons Map.**
Samples collected May, 1966 to September, 1966. Total of 740 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes three maps: (1) Ethane and Propane and Butane Map, (2) Methane Map, and (3) Pentane Map.**
Samples collected April, 1965 to November, 1965. Total of 2269 sampled points. The set of paper maps includes two maps: (1) Ethane and Propane and Butane Map, and (2) Methane Map.**
The original order of the Professor Richard Jonas Papers has been maintained where possible. The collection includes limited correspondence, brochures and directories that relate to health, welfare and various community-related agencies. Most of the materials in the collection date from 1934 to 1978 with the majority dating from the 1950s. Items in the collection relating to the university include the Guidance Office, job evaluation manual, the library, the proposed College of Philosophy and Religion and U.H. veterans. The collection also includes a small portion of personal correspondence, which may provide background information and perspective to the researcher.
This series consists of eight folders, arranged alphabetically. The majority of these contain brochures, bulletins or handouts from various conferences or symposia. The folders date from 1955 to 1969.
This series consists of eighteen folders of brochures, bulletins, newsletters and limited correspondence related to different organizations and associations. Folders are arranged alphabetically and date from 1945 to 1957.
This series is the largest, consisting of 366 folders dating from 1934 to 1986. The materials in this series cover a wide range of university-related topics and it is divided into five sub-series: Administration, Other UH Campuses, Academics, Student Activities and Groups, and Faculty and Staff Activities andGroups. Each sub-series is arranged alphabetically. Due to the positions Jonas held at the university, the folders related to the Guidance Office, library and the Veterans Office contain the most material.
The Ruth Pennybacker Collection consists of the teaching aids she used in class, photocopies of plays, news clippings, and programmes. Included in the collection is a scrapbook crafted in 1967 by her students, colleagues, and friends as a tribute to Miss Pennybacker.
This series contains 24 folders, arranged alphabetically. The majority of these contain news clippings, correspondence and plays used as part of the classroom curriculum.
This series contains 25 folders, arranged alphabetically. These folders consist of spiral notebooks and correspondence from the Play Readers group, organized chronologically from 1978-1981. Also contained in this series are poems, programmes and a copy of Pennybacker's 1934 thesis.
This series contains a scrapbook dated 1967, that contains letters, notes and tributes to Miss Pennybacker. Included in the scrapbook are letters written by Joseph M. Doggett, Philip G. Hoffman, John C. Allred, John Q. Anderson, Vassar Miller, and Kenneth Carbajal.
The Faculty Organizations Records primarily consist of organizational minutes, as well as constitutions, bylaws, and reports. Records include those of the Faculty Association (1954-1963), Faculty Assembly 91951-1959), and Faculty Senate (1969-2005).
This series consists of 10 folders in chronological order and date from 1954-1963. The 1959 Constitution and By-Laws of the organization is also included with this series.
This series consists of eight folders and date from 1951-1959.
This series consists of 30 folders and date from 1969-2005.
The Collection contains materials related to the book, A College Forum, edited by Joseph Doggett, Everett Gillis, and Rosa Bludworth, published by The Odyssey Press in 1963. In the Preface, the editors' arrived at what they considered a special design for their work, seeing a twofold need: "the need of the student for readings that will stimulate his own expression; the need of the instructor for a text that is adaptable to either a subject matter or a types of approach."
The Collection consists of one box and includes the preliminary drafts of the textbook along with the editor's corrections.
The American Association of University Professors, University of Houston Chapter Records consists mainly of documents directly related to the organization including the Constitution, minutes, bank statements, letters, correspondence, membership lists, and newsletters.
The UH Veteran's Office Records contain material pertaining to the university and government-sponsored office for the support and advising of veteran students during the 1940s and 1950s. Dates for items in the collection range from 1944 to 1958, with the bulk of the material dating from the late 1940s.
The collection is arranged into nine series: Veteran's Office, Veteran's Staff Meetings, Budget, Correspondence with Veteran's Administration, Veteran's Administration Field Manual for Training Officers, Guidance Office, Veteran's Service Center, Forms, and Miscellaneous. The original arrangement has been kept intact where possible, however some minor rearrangement was necessary to facilitate research. Material is grouped chronologically within each series. Folder headings used by the originators have been adhered to where possible. For additional information on veteran's affairs at the University of Houston, researchers should also consult the Veteran's Village Records.
There are twenty-one folders in this series containing items dating from 1944 to 1951. Material in this series consists of general correspondence between Veteran's Office personnel and University of Houston administrators, as well as some Veteran's Administration and other assorted letters.
The three folders in this series contain minutes and notes from meetings held from 1946 to 1947.
There are three folders in this series. Material dating from 1948 to August 1949 is largely in the form of ledger sheets and financial summaries.
There are eight folders in this series with material dating from 1947 through 1949. Items focus exclusively on correspondence with the Veteran's Administration. [Note: this material was separated from other general correspondence (i.e., what is now the Veteran's Office series) in the collection's original arrangement.]
The one folder in this series is a guide published in May 1946 by the Vocational Rehabilitation and Education Division of the Houston, Texas Regional VA office. It compiles Veteran's Administration regulations and procedures for personnel working with veterans in higher education. Organizational charts and specific instructions for completing various forms are included.
There are three folders in this series with items dating from 1947 to 1950. Material in this series includes floor plans, a blueprint, and correspondence with university administration concerning the construction of an office space to house the UH Veteran's Office. It also contains specific registration procedures.
The two folders in this series contain material from August 1945 through 1948, and some undated items. It focuses on information dealing with a Veteran's service center located off campus, for ex-military personnel in the greater Houston area.
There are five folders in this series containing various forms and registration material required of veterans by the Veteran's Administration and the University of Houston. Material dates from 1945 to 1950.
The two folders in this series contain material from July 1946 and 1958. Documents include vocational school class lists and a copy of The Wesleyan, a Methodist students' group newsletter.
The Veteran's Village Records contain material dealing with the organization of the Veteran's Council, the UH Veteran's Club, newsletters as well as announcements, petitions, and press releases. Items date from 1945 to 1956 with most of the material dating from the late 1940s and early 1950s.
The collection is arranged into seven series: Constitution, Veterans Club Meetings, Record of Activities Council, Petitions, Press Releases and Announcements, Nursery School, and the Village News (the Village newsletter). The original arrangement has been kept intact where possible, however some minor rearrangement was necessary to facilitate research. Material is arranged chronologically within each series. When possible, folder headings used by the originators have been adhered to in arranging and describing the records.
The folder in this series contains two constitutions for the Veterans Club of the University of Houston. The first version is marked as a copy of the October 1945 document, while the second is a revised copy from September 1955. Each constitution also lists by-laws for the organization.
The four folders in this series include minutes from Veterans Council meetings. Most of the notes are handwritten, apparently by the same person. This individual was likely R. O. Jonas, chief counselor for veterans during the post-war era and a faculty sponsor of the Veterans Club. The material dated 1945 and 1946 appears to have been removed from a notebook and contains several newspaper clippings pertaining to veteran's activities at the university as well as lists of club members.
This series contains a notebook with material dating from 1946 to 1947. Items within the notebook range from minutes of meetings and newsletters, to announcements of activities and correspondence.
There is one folder in this series containing material from 1945. The petition was designed by the Veterans Club to assist veterans who had not received their subsistence allowances during the latter months of 1945.
There is one folder in this series. The bulk of the series content is undated. That which is dated ranges from 1946 to 1947.
There are five folders in this series, with material dating from 1947 and 1948. Each folder is an individual sub-series dealing with different aspects of the creation of a nursery school for the Veterans Village. Items include the initial proposal, administrative policies, purchase orders and requisitions, and a conversion plan.
The six folders in this series contain copies of the Village News from November 1946 through 1950, with some undated items. The Village News chronicles important events in the Veterans Village as well as providing names of council officers for specific areas of the Village.
The UH 50th Anniversary (Half Century) Records arrived at the archives in relatively good order, which has been maintained where possible. The collection consists mainly of documents relating to the various events of the celebration and the committee overseeing the events. Materials include agendas, correspondence, minutes, brochures, forms, calendars, commemorative newspaper articles, and press clippings. The collection dates almost entirely from 1976-1977, with a few items from as late as 1981. The materials are organized into six series: Planning and Preparation; Half Century Events; Media; Personnel; Commemorative Materials; and Afterwards.
This series contains forty folders dating from 1976 to 1978. Whenever possible the original order has been maintained, although some changes have been made to facilitate access. This series has been organized into four sub-series: General Planning, Half Century Brochure, Half Century Forms, and Half Century Logo Use. The folders contain minutes, brochures, mailing lists, meeting notes, programs and invitations, and drafts of various brochures.
This sub-series consists of twelve folders arranged alphabetically. The Planning Committee folders are arranged first by date, then alphabetically.
